awd_titl_txt: ATD: Nonparametric Testing and Fast Computing Methods for Spatiotemporal Models with Applications to Threat Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
The study of human dynamics aims to understand human behaviors using analytical models. It has received substantial attention in the security and defense area not only for its potential in detecting human anomalies but also for its capability in containing potential disastrous damages and mental horror in human society. The recent development in social media has revolutionized daily life and inaugurated a new era in human dynamics study.  It has been demonstrated that certain human behavior can be modeled quantitatively using proxy tools. Social media data and wearable device data are two major sources of proxies that can be used to understand spatiotemporal trends from which we can identify abnormal patterns in human dynamics. The abnormal patterns can be used as an indicator for disasters. Although social media data and wearable device data contain a wealth of information to understanding human behavior, they are constantly evolving as users generate new content or as new routes are introduced. Classic statistical models are not enough to model constantly-evolving spatial and temporal trends. More importantly, the computational cost for a spatiotemporal model is extremely high, which poses a significant challenge for real-time analysis of human dynamics data. To overcome these challenges, we propose novel statistical theory, methods, algorithms for efficiently analyzing local and global trends of a spatiotemporal model. The project will train students to participate in cutting-edge and interdisciplinary big data research.  

Despite the urgent need, statistical tools for human dynamic studies are still lacking. In this project, we aim to develop spatiotemporal models to understand the inherent spatial/temporal trends of social media and personal wearables data. The key challenge for analyzing large-scale spatiotemporal data is the super-large sample size. For example, every day Twitter takes in hundreds of million tweets. Many of these tweets are recorded in public streams.  We develop scalable computational methods to surmount the challenge. The fast, in-network computing principles and middleware developed in this project are fundamental and indispensable tools for "big data" computation and autonomous systems. The proposed framework can be used to discover unusual events in any super-large dynamic data set and inspire a new line of research in big data analytics. The proposed statistical tools are widely applicable in science, engineering, and humanities. The research will be conducted in collaboration with experts in both geography and statistics; consequently, the proposed work will be informed by rapid empirical feedback and can incorporate modern advances in spatiotemporal modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to study human dynamics by applying advanced analytical models to better understand human behavior. As social media platforms and wearable technologies continue to shape modern life, the need for detecting behavioral anomalies has become increasingly urgent, particularly in the context of disaster prevention and threat detection. The overarching goal of this project was to develop scalable spatiotemporal models capable of analyzing vast, evolving datasets from sources such as social media and wearable devices. These models would provide real-time insights into human behavior, enabling timely responses to potential threats or disasters.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in addressing the critical challenge of modeling spatiotemporal data, particularly at the scale required by today’s massive datasets. Traditional models fall short when dealing with platforms like Twitter, which processes millions of tweets each day. To overcome this, we developed innovative statistical tools and algorithms designed to analyze both local and global trends within spatiotemporal data. A key innovation in this project was the creation of nonparametric testing methods based on Smoothing Spline ANOVA models, which enabled the detection of abnormal temporal or spatial patterns. These patterns, which may signal early warnings for disasters or security threats, represent valuable insights for sectors such as security and defense. One of the most significant contributions of this project was the development of decentralized computing algorithms, which allow for the rapid processing of large-scale datasets with spatiotemporal dependencies. These algorithms are crucial for real-time applications, where traditional spatiotemporal models face high computational costs. By decentralizing the computational workload, our approach made large-scale spatiotemporal analysis not only feasible but also cost-efficient. This capability is essential for any system that seeks to provide timely, real-time monitoring and response capabilities. In addition to the innovations in spatiotemporal modeling, we introduced a new method called Bayesian Knowledge Distillation (BKD) to address challenges in uncertainty quantification within knowledge distillation (KD) frameworks. KD is widely used for model compression and deployment acceleration, but its effectiveness in managing uncertainty had been limited. BKD enhances this process by offering transparent interpretations of KD mechanisms and providing Bayesian inference tools for quantifying uncertainty in the student model. This advancement is particularly valuable for improving the reliability of compressed models, making it easier to deploy deep learning models in sensitive fields, such as medical AI, where data privacy and accuracy are paramount.

The broader impacts of this project extend across multiple disciplines, making the results relevant not only to statistics and geography but also to public safety, engineering, and even the humanities. The spatiotemporal models and computational frameworks we developed have the potential to improve disaster management and public safety by enabling early detection of abnormal behaviors. For example, the models could be used to analyze behavioral patterns from social media or wearable devices to detect potential threats in schools or public spaces. In this context, our minimax test, developed as part of the project, offers a rigorous statistical method for detecting behavioral changes and serves as an early warning system for potential risks. The project also made significant contributions to the field of big data computation. The scalable computational methods and middleware we developed are essential tools for managing large-scale datasets, enabling efficient and timely detection of unusual events. These methods are not only crucial for real-time monitoring but are also vital for privacy-aware, resource-efficient machine learning models, particularly in scenarios where rapid decision-making is necessary. Our work responds to the growing demand for robust, reliable machine learning systems in real-world applications, where the balance between efficiency and privacy is often difficult to achieve.

To summarize, this project made significant advances in the field of spatiotemporal modeling by developing novel nonparametric methods capable of capturing evolving spatial and temporal trends in large datasets sourced from social media and wearable devices. These methods enable real-time analysis of human behavior, allowing for the detection of spatiotemporal anomalies that may signal potential threats. In addition, our work on Bayesian Knowledge Distillation provides a bridge toward safely deploying pre-trained deep learning models in privacy-sensitive domains. This is especially important in ensuring both data privacy and model accuracy is critical. The computational challenges inherent in analyzing massive datasets were addressed through the development of decentralized computing algorithms, ensuring that real-time processing is both feasible and cost-effective. Furthermore, this project fostered interdisciplinary collaboration between experts in fields such as geography and statistics, incorporating the latest innovations from both domains.
